loans.name: Amarbayasgalan

texts.en:
Mr. Amarbayasgalan is 32 years old single. He lives in a "ger," a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He rents a stall in Bumbugur, the second largest indoor market in Ulaanbaatar, where he sells jeans. 

Before 2009, he worked in Korea on a labor contract. When he returned to Mongoloia, he used his savings to start a retail jeans business. Currently his business is doing well and he has gained some valuable experience. He has two younger brothers whom he supports by paying their annual student fees. 

Lately, he has been studying the shoe sales market and decided to sell shoes, too. He needs to increase his working capital to stock some shoes. 

Mr.Amarbayasgalan is planning a quite few improvements in the near future, such as building a house, marrying his fiancee, and opening his own small shop. He is a very ambitious and energetic person. The loan will be used to buy shoes and jeans to sell.

loans.use: To increase his working capital and to buy shoes and jeans to sell

loans.name: Abbasgulu

texts.ru:
Abbasgulu Y. 42 sqoda. On yavlyayetsya IDP personom, pereselenec iz Fuzuli regiona i seychas projivayet v Absheron regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. 

Abbasgulu uje 7 let kak rabotayet masnikom, etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo dyadi kotoriy i pomoq yemu zanatsya etim biznesom. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit maso dlya pereprodaji i razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa.
texts.en: Abbasgulu Y., 42, is an internally displaced person who had to resettle from the Fuzuli region to the Absheron region with his family. He has been working as a butcher for seven years. He learned this trade from his uncle, who also helped Abbasgulu start this business. Abbasgulu is applying for a 2000 AZN loan that would allow him to buy meat for resale and increase turnover.

loans.use: to purchase meat for resale

loans.name: San Juan Masias Group

texts.es:
María tiene un puesto en el mercado de su zona su negocio es la venta de menestras cocidas como lentejas, frejoles, trigos etc. Ella empezó en esto gracias a una buena amiga que le dio la idea de vender estos alimentos, debido a que muchas personas por el apuro buscaban menestras cocidas y al ver que nadie ofrecía este tipo de producto se animo, al inicio preparaba pocas cantidades solo algunos kilos de menestras aun así muchas veces no vendía mucho y le sobraba pero ya le servía para alimentar a su familia con el tiempo su negocio creció, ahora las cantidades de menestras que prepara son mayores y no solo eso también vende verduras picadas, ensaladas frescas y cocidas María siempre trata de ofrecer lo mejor a sus  caceras, aparte de variedad ofrece limpieza al preparar los alimentos que vende, su mayor inversión es tener su casa propia quiere terminarla por que mas adelante alquilara los departamentos que allí construye esto será un ingreso adicional que espera concretar pronto, también esta próxima a comprarse una moto que le servirá para el traslado de sus insumos a su puesto de venta esto será un ahorro mas para su negocio ,el préstamo que EDAPROSPO le otorga como parte del grupo el grupo “SAN JUAN MASIAS” le servirá para comprar menestras y verduras que ofrecerá a sus fieles compradores.

*La Sra. María M. es la del medio esta con polo negro y pantalón fuccia.
texts.en:
María has a market stall in her area where she sells cooked pulses and grains such as lentils, beans, wheat, etc.  She started in her business thanks to a good friend who gave her the idea of selling these products.  Many people, through hardship, were looking to buy cooked pulses and when she saw that nobody offered this type of product, she became encouraged.  At first she prepared small quantities, only a few kilos.  Even so, she often didn't sell much and had some left over which she served up to her family. 

Over time, María's business grew.  Now she prepares larger quantities of pulses.  She also sells chopped vegetables, fresh salads and cooked salads.  María always tries to offer the best to her customers.  As well as the variety, she also offers cleanliness in preparing the food that she sells.  Her biggest investment is owning her own home.  She would like to finish it because in the future she would like to rent out the apartments that she is building there.  This would be an additional income that she hopes to have soon.  She is also close to buying a motorbike which will help her transport her supplies to her sales stall and this will be another saving for her business.

María will use the loan that she will receive from EDAPROSPO as part of the 'San Juan Masias' group to buy pulses and vegetables that she will offer to her loyal customers.

* Mrs María M. is the lady in the middle of the photo wearing a black top and fuscia-colored pants.

loans.use: To buy pulses and vegetables

loans.name: Kisa Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Fifty-six-year-old Josephine N. has been operating her medical clinic for the past 23 years in Kalagi-Mukono. Her client base is diverse. She began this business after she finished school. She says she was previously selling maize. Hard work, she says, has enabled her achieve this longevity.

This business brings in 200,000 shillings each month and this happily married mother of one says she she is going to use the proceeds from this loan to buy more drugs. She belongs to Kisa Development Group-Mukono.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for his medical clinic

loans.name: Naile

texts.ru:
Naile F. 22 qoda. Ona ne zamujem i jivet v Asbheron regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. Naile uje 2 qoda kak imeyet svayo kafe qde ona sama i rabotayet, etomu biznessu yeyo nauchila tetya kotoroya pomoqla otkrit eto kafe.
Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit stoli i stulya dlya svoyeqo kafe. Naile v budushem xochet xorosho razvit svoy bizness i v budushem uvelichit pomesheniye svoyeqo kafe.
texts.en: Naile F., 22, is married. She resides in Absheron with her family. Two years ago her aunt helped her open a cafe, where Naile works. Naile is applying for a loan of 2000 AZN, which she would like to use for the purchase of tables and chairs. In the future, Naile is planning to expand her business and get a larger room.

loans.use: to purchase tables and chairs for her cafe

loans.name: Aku Elom

texts.fr: Elom est âgée de 32 ans.  Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus, la vente de produits d’alimentation.  Elle a débuté en 2005 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Elle a ouvert une boutique dans son domicile où elle revend les produits. Elle demande un prêt pour acheter  5 cartons de pâtes, 10 cartons de tomates, 20 sacs de riz, et 100 cartons de boissons de canettes.
texts.en: Elom is 32 years old and has a revenue-generating business selling grocery items.  She started in 2005 and gets her supplies at the big market of Lomé, the capital of Togo.  Elom opened her store within her home, where she sells these goods.  She is asking for a loan to buy 5 boxes of pasta, 10 boxes of tomatoes, 20 sacks of rice, and 100 boxes of beverages in cans.

loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Corazon De Jesus Group

texts.es:
El grupo “CORAZON D. JESUS” esta formado por 10 miembros, este es su primer desembolso y tienen muchas expectativas y metas que quieren alcanzar, todas son vecinas y amigas del distrito los Olivos Lima Peru, L. presidenta del grupo es L. Sra. CarL. quien tiene un negocio D. costura todo empezó cuando a su esposo le dieron una maquina D. cocer como parte D. pago animada por el fue que empezó a estudiar corte y confección en un centro ocupacional, con lo aprendido ofreció sus servicios a sus amistades mas cercanas y vecinos, elL. hace arreglos, composturas, y cose ropa a L. medida como vestidos, blusas, pantalones etc. Con su trabajo elL. pueD. ayudar a su esposo que algunas veces queda desempleado ya que es un trabajador independiente, así ambos con mucho esfuerzo han podido construir su casa que consideran un logro importante es allí donD. elL. quiere poner un taller mas granD. y completo donD. también pueda ofrecer a sus clientes otro servicios como alquiler D. vestidos para toda ocasión, es justamente en ese proyecto que invertirá su préstamo ya que le falta algunos arreglos para terminar lo que muy pronto será  el taller D. costura que tanto ha deseado.

	*CarL. H. viste  casaca y polo morado, es L. octava D. las paradas
texts.en:
The group “Corazon D. Jesus” is maD. up of ten members, all of whom are neighbours and friends from the Olivos district in Lima, Peru. This is their first loan together and they have many hopes and dreams that they want to fulfill. 

CarL. is the president of their group. She runs a sewing business which she began when her husband received a sewing machine as part of a payment. Encouraged by him, CarL. began to study dressmaking in an occupational centre. Using the skills that she learnt at the centre, CarL. offered her services to her close friends and neighbours, carrying out repairs, alterations and making clothes to measure including dresses, shirts, pants, etc. 

With this work CarL. can help her husband who sometimes goes through periods of unemployment as he is self employed. Together and with a lot of effort, CarL. and her husband were able to build their house, which they consider to be an important achievement. Now CarL. would like to build a bigger and more elaborate workshop in their house where she can offer her customers other services, including clothes hire for all occasions. This is the project that she intends to invest her loan into once construction is finished on what will soon be the sewing workshop that she has wanted for so long.

	*CarL. H. is wearing a purple jumper and jacket and is the eighth person standing

loans.use: Complete construction of a sewing workshop

loans.name: Ayi

texts.fr: Ayi  est mariée et âgé de 44 ans.  Il est information de profession et a ouvert   à  cet effet  un cyber.  Il  a associe le traitement texte  et compte dans cette activité 6 ans. A travers cette activité beaucoup de crédits sont déjà remboursés.  IL sollicite un prêt pour acquérir 30 cartons de papier rame, 1 imprimante,  2 boite de CD,  et faire en même  temps l’entretien des ordinateurs.
texts.en: Ayi is 44 years old and is married. He is a computer specialist by profession and so he has opened a cyber cafe. He also does word processing and has been involved in this activity for 6 years. Through his business, he has already repaid many loans. He is asking  for  a loan to buy 30 boxes of paper, 1 printer, 2 boxes of CDs and at the same time to perform maintenance on the computers.

loans.use: To buy computer-related materials

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is currently in the business of selling wax and clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more wax and clothes to sell.  Rose is 30 years old and married to a police officer. She has two children. One of the children goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock more wax and clothes to sell

loans.name: Vidadi

texts.ru:
Vidadi Y. 57 let. On jenat i imeyet 4 detey dvoya iz kotorix uchatsya v kolledje i dva iz kotorix uchatsya v shkole. Vidadi yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli regiona i seychas jivet v Absheron regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. 

Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit ovoshi frukti dlya pereprodaji. Etomu biznessu prodaji fruktov ovoshey on nauchislay u svoyeqo otca ,Vidadi uje 8 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom.
texts.en: Vidadi Y., 57, is married with four children. Two of them children go to college and two are still in school. Vidadi is an internally displaced person whose family had to resettle from Fuzuli to Absheron. Vidadi is applying for a loan of 2000 AZN. This money would help him buy fruit and vegetables for retail sale. Having learned this trade from his father, Vidadi has been in this business for eight years.

loans.use: to purchase fruit and vegetables for retail sale

loans.name: Djafar

texts.ru:
Djafar K. 52 qoda. On jenat  i imeyet 3 detey odin iz nix uchitsya v universitete a dvoya uchatsya v kolledje. Djafar i yeqo lubimaya semya jivut v Absheron regione uje 7 let. 

Djafar uje 8 let zanimayetsya etim biznessom prodaji odejdi , etomu biznessu yeqo nauchil starshiy brat. Seychas on nujdayestya v 2000 AZN chtobi sdelat polki v maqazine i kupit tovar dlya pereprodaji.
texts.en: Djafar K., 52, is married with three children. One of them is a university student and the other two are at college. Djafar and his dear family have been living in the Absheron region for seven years. Djafar's elder brother helped him start his business of selling clothes. Djafar is applying for a loan that would allow him to build shelves and buy goods for increasing turnover.

loans.use: to build shelves in the shop and purchase goods for resale

loans.name: Djiguiya   (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Djiguiya est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les fruits et légumes, les habillements,  les céréales, la petite restauration etc. 
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 6 ans. Elles sont à leur quatorzième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Fatoumata S. est un membre du groupe Djiguiya qui vend des sandwiches.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, chaque jour des miches de pain, de la viande et tous les ingrédients nécessaires pour la préparation du sandwich. Elle achète son pain à la boulangerie, la viande et les ingrédients sont achetés au grand marché de Koutiala. Elle vend le sandwich en face de l’école du quartier Koko, au comptant sur une table bien propre qui attire les élèves à la recréation et bien d’autres gens du voisinage. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Djiguiya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 115 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Fatoumata S. compte réaliser 130 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Djiguiya is a group of women who live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. On average they are 40 years old, are married and have at least 5 children.

This group of women sells various products such as fruits and vegetables, clothes, cereals, snacks, etc. To increase their activity, 6 years ago they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. They are on their fourteenth group loan and all previous loans have been properly repaid. 

Fatoumata S. is a member of the Djiguiya group and sells sandwiches. She plans to use her loan to buy bread, meat and other ingredients needed for sandwiches each day. She buys her bread from the bakery, meat and other ingredients are purchased at the grand market in Koutiala. Fatoumata sells her sandwiches for cash opposite the Koko neighborhood school, using a clean table to attract students at recess as well as many other people form the area. 

While other members of the Djiguiya group plan to make an average profit of 115,000 CFA francs each during this period, Fatoumata plans to make 130,000 CFA francs. Besides repaying loans, the women use part of the income to meet their current household expenses.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for sandwiches

loans.name: Nguvu Moja Group

texts.en:
Magreth S. is in her early twenties. She is a single mother of a four-month-old baby. Magreth has been running two businesses for the past four months. Her main business is a fruit and vegetable stall, but she also sells used clothing. Both businesses are open from 07:00 a.m. to 06:00 p.m. and earn Magreth a small monthly profit. 

This will be Magreth's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She aims to use the loan to improve the condition of her vegetable stall and stock up on more second-hand clothes. Magreth's goal is to use her profit to improve the conditions of her new room, into which she has recently moved. 

Magreth will share this loan with her loan group, Nguvu Moja, which totals 18 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying their loans. 

In the picture, Magreth on the far right with a small baby in her lap.

loans.use: Improve her fruit and vegetable stall and buy more second-hand clothes

loans.name: Mcharuko Group

texts.en:
Stephania K., who is in her early fifties, is married and has two children. Stephania has been running a small fish business for the past eight years. Open between 08:00 am and 08:00 pm daily, the business earns her a low monthly profit.

This will be Stephania's fifth loan with Tujijenge Tanzania, her previous loans having been used to expand the business and make more capital available to buy additional fish when needed. These loans have all been repaid. With her fifth loan, Stephania aims to make improvements to her stall, which is not in very good condition at the moment. Stephania's dream is to one day build herself her own house.

Stephania will share this loan with her loan group Mcharuko. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Stephania is in front in a black dress.

loans.use: To make improvements to her fish stall.

loans.name: Tung

texts.en: Tung S. is 54 years old, married, and the mother of five children: two are still single and attending school and the other two are married and are employed as grocery sellers. Tung S. and her husband cultivate rice and vegetable crops and she is also a tailor. Tun S. will use the loan money to buy farming supplies and the rest to repair her plowing machine.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies and the rest to repair her plowing machine.

loans.name: Lem

texts.en: Lem C. sells a few wares in front of her home such as soft drink, sweets, and some cooking supplies. To meet the family’s living expenses, her husband works as a boat driver on the river. The couple has four children, all of them single who live under her roof. Recently, part of Lem C.’s inventory has been exhausted; she is requesting a loan to replenish it.

loans.use: To accumulate inventory.

loans.name: Byambajav

texts.en: Byambajav S. is 55 years old and a single mother who lives with her four children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. Her oldest daughter helps her with the business, two others attend university and her other daughter works in the local theater. Byambajav operates a timber, wood items, and wooden frame trading business. She started her business in 2006 after previously operating a meat business at the local trade center. After many years owing a business, she has gained much experience as a businesswoman and has built a stable and successful operation. For the future, Byambajav hopes to expand her business by establishing a new sales chanel with Germany. She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to buy two ornamented ger frames for her wooden item trading business.

loans.use: To buy ornamented wooden ger (tent housing) frames

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: Sang B. is a single mother caring for two children, both of whom attend the local school and are dependent on her income. She was married years ago, but divorced her husband. She is a sacrificing and determined woman who tries to earn money to ensure that her children attain the highest level of education. To earn a living, she sells fresh beef and dessert to people who are passers-by in the village. Sang B. will use the loan as extra capital to sustain her business growth. This will allow her to gain more income and more valued customers. Sang B. hopes that she can use the rest of her fund to add to her personal savings to purchase a used motorbike for her family.

loans.use: To use as extra capital to sustain her business growth.

loans.name: Bumnamjid

texts.en: Bumnamjid P. is 28 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. Her oldest daughter attends secondary school and her youngest is in kindergarden. P. sells firewood, and her husband runs a carpentry business. In Bayan-Ulgii province, there is high demand as many residents live in gers (housing tents) and therefore need wood for ger frames and also as firewood, especially during winter months. P. and her husband hire a driver and large truck, travel to a nearby forest, collect old wood, and transport it to the province center to sell. Her husband started his carpentry business in 2000 but already had much experience in carpentery after helping his father in the business since he was a child. The  couple now sells coal in addition to firewood. Their business has found success and they are able to improve their family's quality of life such as buying furniture and household equipment. P. is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: H. Philomène

texts.fr: H. Philomène est née en 1950 à Savalou dans le département des Collines au Bénin. Mariée à un certain ZODANKPO, Philomène est mère de quatre enfants dont seulement un est à sa charge. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Il y a près de vingt cinq ans que Philomène habite le quartier Avotrou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Philomène n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Philomène mène comme activité la vente de maïs et de façon secondaire, la vente de charbon de bois à son domicile. Philomène s'approvisionne dans le Nord du Bénin. Philomène exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d'année et a déjà obtenu cinq crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a remboursés. Dans le but d'agrandir davantage son activité et augmenter son chiffre d'affaire pendant cette période de fête de nouvel an, Philomène sollicite à nouveau un autre crédit.
texts.en: H.Philomene was born in 1950 in Savalou, in the Collines Department  of Benin. Married to a Mr. Zondakpo, Philomee is the mother of four children, only one of whom is now in her care. Some of her children study.  For about 25 years, Philomene has been living in the Avotrou district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The spouses jointly take care of the family budget. Philomene did not attend school. In order to support herself, Philomene sells corn; as a secondary business activity, she sells charcoal out of her home. Philomene stocks up in the north of Benin. She has been in this line of business for about a dozen years, and had five prior loans from ALIDé, all repaid. With the goal of growing her business and increasing her revenues during this holiday season before the new year, Philomene is seeking a new loan.

loans.use: Purchasing bags of corn

loans.name: Nuraiym Murzabekova's Group

texts.en:
Nuraiym M. is the treasurer of this group. She is 23 and married. Her husband works in construction. Together they bring up two daughters. In order to earn extra money to cover family expenses, Nuraiym breeds livestock. She started this activity three years ago with an initial investment of 14,000 KGS. Now, by reselling livestock after fattening she earns 2,000 KGS per month. With this loan, Nuraiym wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future she wants to build a shop near her house and start selling convenience goods.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Ainura Abdieva's Group

texts.en:
Ainura A. is the leader of this group. She is 39, married and has three sons and a daughter. Her first son studies at university and the other children are at school. In order to earn money, Ainura and her husband breed livestock. They resell livestock at a higher price after fattening. In this way the family earns 6,000 KGS per month. With this loan, Ainura wants to purchase livestock for breeding. In the future, she plans to celebrate the wedding of her first son.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Oyunbaatar

texts.en:
Mr.Oyunbaatar 27, lives with his wife in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They are expecting a baby in January 2011. Since 2006, Oyunbaatar has been running a taxi business quite successfully, and in 2008 he bought a car off a leasing contract, paying it off in 2009. Last year he took a loan from us and managed to buy a ger to live in. The loan was paid off on time. Oyunbaatar is one of our many reliable customers.

This time he is applying for another loan to buy some spare parts and to repair and service his car. The taxi business is the family's only source of income at the moment. A very nice and hard working person, Oyunbaatar is planning to build a family house in the near future.

loans.use: To buy spare parts and repair and service his car

loans.name: Latifatou

texts.fr: Latifatou est née le 23 Juin 1976 à Bassila au Nord du Bénin. Latifatou est mariée à Doumouni et est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Latifatou vit depuis huit ans environs à Finagnon, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, avec sa famille. Latifatou assure ensemble avec son mari les diverses charges de la maison. Latifatou n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour répondre à ses besoins quotidiens, Latifatou vend depuis une douzaine d'année divers produits (sardine, sucre, pâtes alimentaires, couscous, lait, allumette, savons, etc.) par le système de distribution. De façon secondaire, Latifatou vend de l'huile à moteur. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Latifatou achète ses produtis. Latifatou avait bénéficié antérieurement de quatre prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés, malgré quelques problèmes qu'elle a rencontrés. Latifatou désire renforcer son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle en période de fête de fin d'année ; raison pour laquelle Latifatou sollicite un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Latifatou was born 23 June 1976 in Bassila, in the North of Benin. She is married to Doumouni and is the mother of five children, all attending (or having attended) school.

Latifatou has been living for eight years with her family in the Finagnon borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She manages with her husband the various household expenses.

To meet her daily needs over the past twelve years, Latifatou has been selling various products through the distribution system (sardines, sugar, pasta, cuscus, milk, matches, soap, etc.). She also sells motor oil as a side business. She buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. 

Latifatou had already been granted four previous loans, all of which have been repaid in full, despite her experiencing a few problems. She wants to strengthen her activity and improve customer response during year-end festivities, which is why she is requesting another loan.

loans.use: Buy various products (cartons of sardines, soap, sugar, pasta, etc.)

loans.name: Chynara Ibragimova's Group

texts.en:
Chynara I. is the leader of this group. She is 32, married, and has three daughters and a son. Seven years ago, with an initial investment of 30,000 KGS, Chynara and her husband started to breed livestock. Reselling livestock after fattening they earn 6,000 KGS per month. Chynara hopes to obtain this loan because she needs money to purchase a washing-machine in order to improve her living conditions. In the future, she wants to increase her number of livestock to be able to support her children financially.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a washing machine

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity S. is 34 years old and married to a builder. She has three children, who all go to school. Charity is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a small restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs such as raw meat, rice, beans etc. to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar.

loans.use: To stock more foodstuffs such as raw meat, rice, beans etc.

loans.name: Rahat Satybaldieva's Group

texts.en:
Rahat S. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Kerben, a small town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. Rahat is 27 and married to a builder. She has a daughter and a son, both of preschool age (under 7).
Rahat is engaged in cattle breeding. She resells cattle after fattening and has been in this business for four years. With this loan, Rahat wants to purchase cattle for breeding.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Estelle

texts.fr: Estelle est née le 16 Septembre 1971 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Estelle est mariée à un plombier, Lambert, et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Estelle vit avec sa famille au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis vingt ans environs. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Estelle a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour se prendre en charge et nourrir sa famille, Estelle  vend du charbon de bois et également des cartes de recharge téléphonique depuis seize ans environs. Estelle s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. A l'approche des fêtes de nouvel an, Estelle sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer ses activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Estelle was born 16 September 1971 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Lambert, a plumber, and is mother to four children, all attending (or having attended) school. For the past 20 years she has lived with her family in the Finagnon borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The couple shares responsibility for the various family expenses.

Estelle interrupted her schooling at secondary level. To take charge of herself and feed her family she has been selling charcoal and prepaid phone cards over the past 16 years. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace.

She is a former ALIDé client who reimburses her loans well. With approaching year-end festivities she is requesting a new loan from ALIDé, aiming to strengthen her activity and improve customer satisfaction.

loans.use: Buy sacks of charcoal and prepaid phione cards

loans.name: Mathilde

texts.fr: Mathilde est née le 16 Mars 1967 et est mariée à Bernadin. Le couple a quatre enfants tous scolarisés, dont trois sont à leur charge. Mathilde vit avec sa famille à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis près de vingt ans. Mathilde assure avec son mari les divers besoins de la famille. Mathilde a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Mathilde vend depuis environs seize ans, diverses sortes de bouteilles à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Mathilde est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de ses clients et à l'approche de la période de fête de fin d'année, Mathilde désire renforcer son activité pour mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C'est ce qui l'amène à solliciter un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Mathilde was born 16 March 1967 and is married to Bernadin. The couple have four children, all attending (or having attended) school, of whom three are still under their care. For the past 20 years Mathilde has been living with her family in Agblangandan in the Sèmè-Podji district.

Mathilde manages with her husband the various family expenses. She interrupted her schooling at secondary level. To meet her needs and those of her family over the past 16 years, she has been selling different kinds of bottles in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace.

Mathilde is a former client of ALIDé's, having been granted five loans, all of which were repaid in full. Faced with increasing customer demands and approaching the period of year-end festivities, Mathilde wants to strengthen her activity and better respond to customer requests. That is why she is requesting another loan.

loans.use: Buy bottles

loans.name: Igor

texts.en:
Igor is married with two sons. He is a farming entrepreneur from Kamenka. Igor owns two big greenhouses and grows vegetables for sale. He started this business 11 years ago. Currently, he grows 3,000 tall-grown tomatoes every year. Igor has invested 25,000 UAH in this business. His expenses on seeds and polyethylene film amount to 10,000 to 13,000 UAH every year.
Igor is seeking a loan of 7,500 UAH to construct an additional greenhouse for tomato seedlings. He has potential for further growth and development of his business. Igor is planning to construct a few more greenhouses in the future.

loans.use: To construct an additional greenhouse for seedlings

loans.name: S. Irène

texts.fr: Née en 1964 à Ekpè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, S. Irène vit depuis son jeune âge dans ce quartier. Irène est mariée à un cultivateur du nom de Christophe et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Irène n'a pas été à l'école. Depuis une douzaine d'année, Irène mène comme activité la vente de bouillie (fait à base de farine de maïs) accompagné de pâtés (fait à base de farine de blé) à son domicile et de façon ambulante. Irène achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la deuxième fois que Irène sollicite l'appui financier de ALIDé, en vue d'élever le niveau de son activité et d'accroître son revenu. Irène a bien effectué le remboursement de son premier crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1964 in Ekpé in the Sèmè-Podji district, Irene S. spent her childhood in this neighborhood. She is married to a farmer named Christophe and is the mother of four children, all attending (or having attended) school. The couple shares responsibility for the various family expenses.

Irene has not attended school. For over twelve years her business activity has been to sell corn mush with pâtés (based on wheat flour), from her home and as an itinerant vendor. She buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace.

This is the second time Irene has requested a loan from ALIDé, to increase the activity level of her business and therefore her income. She fully reimbursed the first loan.

loans.use: Buy bags of corn and wheat flour, sugar

loans.name: Pavel

texts.en:
Pavel is married with an eight-year-old son Daniel. He lives in Kamenka. Pavel grows tomatoes for further wholesale and retail sale in different regions of Ukraine. He grows 8,000 tall-grown tomatoes every year. Pavel has eight big greenhouses. He has been growing vegetables for 13 years. Pavel has invested 180,000 UAH in his business. His annual expenses on seeds and polyethylene film amount to 40,000 UAH.
Pavel is seeking a loan of 15,000 UAH to purchase coal for heating in greenhouses, fertilizers and polyethylene film, as well as to install a dripping irrigation system in his greenhouses. Pavel already has plastic polyethylene film for the first protection layer of his greenhouses. However, in Ukraine temperatures usually drop below freezing in early spring, which could ruin his crops. Therefore, Pavel needs to buy additional polyethylene film to protect his future crops. Eventually, he is hoping to install heating units in all eight greenhouses to ensure better protection of his vegetables and minimize costs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, coal, polyethylene film and install a dripping irrigation system in greenhouses

loans.name: Rozakan Arzybaeva's Group

texts.en:
Rozakan A. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tashkomur, a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 61 and unfortunately a widow. She has raised a daughter, 36, who went to work in Russia. In order to earn money to cover her personal expenses, Rozakan breeds livestock. Reselling some farm animals after fattening she earns 5,000 KGS per month.  With this loan, she wants to purchase a calf for breeding. In the near future, she plans to start repairing her house.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married with a grown son, Igor. She is a farmer from Kamenka. Natalya grows early spring vegetables. She owns four big heated greenhouses and two separate farming land lots. Natalya has been working in agriculture for 26 years. She has already invested about 85,000 UAH in this business. Her expenses on seeds and polyethylene film amount to 20,000 to 23,000 UAH.
Natalya is requesting a loan of 15,000 UAH to be invested in construction of a new greenhouse. Natalya is hoping to build several more greenhouses in the future thus expanding her business. In addition to her farming business, Natalya has recently opened a grocery store that she runs with her husband.

loans.use: To invest in construction of a new greenhouse

loans.name: Gulmira Turdalieva's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira T. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tashkomur, a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 30 and married to a miner. Together they bring up two daughters and a son. In 2002, with an initial investment 1,500 KGS, Gulmira bought three sheep and started to breed livestock. In eight years she has increased the number of livestock to seven. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase five more farm animals in order to increase her number of livestock. 

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Kanym

texts.en:
Kanym N. is 54 years old and has five grown children. She lives in Ozgorush village in the north of Kyrgyzstan. Kanym has worked as a milker in the local area for a long time. Her colleagues characterize her as an openhearted and hardworking person. Along with her family, Kanym breeds cattle and cultivates kidney beans and perennial herbs. She has worked hard to improve her business and achieve success. Today, Kanym has a farm with milk cows and she sells their milk to the local dairy factory.
  
Kanym plans to use her loan of 70,000 KGS to increase the number of cows she has and to purchase mineral fertilizers and manure to improve her harvest and farm products. In the future, she plans to build a barn to provide better conditions for her livestock.  

About Bai-Tushum and Partners:

Bai-Tushum and Partners use Kiva funding to target especially vulnerable populations. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading micro-finance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cows and fertilizer

loans.name: Bogdana

texts.en:
Bogdana is single. She is a small entrepreneur from Ivano-Frankivsk where she sells sweaters, bathrobes and terry robes in the central marketplace called ‘Trayan’. Bogdana’s inventory offers a nice selection of items that meet different tastes. She has been in this business for four years and her monthly net income amounts to 8,000 UAH.
Bogdana is seeking a loan of 8,000 UAH to purchase assorted men’s and women’s terry robes and sweaters. She is also hoping to generate additional income to be able to plan her wedding this spring. Moreover, Bogdana has just started a second business – a travel agency called ‘Sunny Tour’ downtown in her home town. It has been established for about six months. She is hoping to see both of her ventures grow and expand in the future.

loans.use: To purchase terry robes and sweaters for resale

loans.name: Maama

texts.en: Maama E. is married and has four children. Her husband is a driver. She sells bags of charcoal, which she has been doing for the past four years. She helps her husband take care of the family.  Maama will use the loan to buy bags of charcoal to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to build a bigger store to keep her charcoal.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Colette

texts.fr: Née en 1969 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, Colette est mariée à Benjamin, un pêcheur, et est mère de cinq enfants tous scolarisés. Colette vit ensemble avec sa famille depuis six ans à Ekpè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Colette vient en aide à son mari en contribuant aux dépenses familiales grâce au revenu que lui apporte son activité. Colette n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Il y a environs dix ans que Colette mène comme activité la vente de poissons frais dans sa boutique à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa et aussi au Port de pêche que Colette  s'approvisionne. En vue de renforcer son activité et d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire en cette période de fête de fin d'année, Colette sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le premier prêt a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
Born in 1969 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Colette is married to Benjamin, a fisherman, and is the mother of five children, all attending (or having attended) school.

For the past six years Colette has been living with her family in Ekpè, in the Sèmè-Podji district. She assists her husband by contributing to family expenses through income generated by her activity.

Colette has not attended school. About ten years ago she started a business activity selling fresh fish from her home-based shop. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa and also from the fisherman’s wharf.

Wanting to bolster her activity and increase her turnover in this period of year-end festivities, Colette is requesting a second loan from ALIDé. The first loan was duly reimbursed.

loans.use: Buy fish

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is the father of three school-age children. He works hard because he is the main income provider for his family. He has eight years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 2002. He uses plastic tents to grow his products. These tents also allow him to better monitor product quality as well as grow his products for more months during the year. He works independently in his business. He cultivates citrus fruit products. Today he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work.  He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15%. In the future, he is hoping to start large-scale farming.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en:
Anahit M. is 59 years old, married, and has three adult children. Anahit worked at Ijevan High School as a teacher until she retired on a pension. In 2001 she and her husband organized their own business in a rented space. This business consists of food and mixed product sales. During these years they have built up their own shop and have bought furniture for their house. Anahit’s shop has a reputation in Ijevan of having the cheapest products for retail and wholesale purchasing. 

Thanks to her first Kiva loan Anahit increased her shop assortment, which allowed her to have a good income. This permitted her and her husband to repair a part of their house and to add a story to their shop, which is situated in their house’s yard. Anahit and her husband are also managing a gift shop in the new addition. 
 
Anahit is requesting a loan for 1,000,000 AMD to buy food wholesale and New Year’s gifts for her shop. With future income she intends to complete her house construction.  This is Anahit’s sixth loan from Nor Horizon and her second loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase food wholesale and New Year’s gifts for her shop

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
A married mother of four children. Nana K. sells a variety of items including maize, meat and doughnuts in Takoradi. Her husband is a farmer, and Nana uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She will use the loan to purchase more flour and other ingredients to fry doughnuts for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nana plans to provide a meaningful education to her children.

The photo shows Nana frying doughnuts.

loans.use: To purchase more flour and other ingredients to fry doughnuts for sale.

loans.name: Leonid

texts.en:
Leonid is married with two grown children. He is a market entrepreneur from the town of Berdyansk in the south of Ukraine. Leonid sells small retail items, i.e. sockets, drills, extension cords, etc., in one of the local markets of his hometown. He is always friendly with his customers. Leonid’s prices are average and affordable for most of his clients. Leonid has been in this trade for 15 years.  

Leonid is seeking a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to increase the selection of retail items he offers for sale in his kiosk. One of his business plans is to buy another vending facility and open one more location to sell his merchandise. The current loan will bring Leonid one step closer to making his business a successful venture, bringing him and his family much-needed stable income.

loans.use: To increase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Saliykan's Group

texts.en: Saliykan K. is the leader of this group. She is 45 and married. Her husband works in the hydro-electric station. She has a daughter, 17, who will graduates from school this year. Saliykan herself is engaged in cattle breeding. She started this activity five years ago with the initial investment 3,000 soms. By reselling cattle after fattening them, she makes 2,000 soms per month. Saliykan hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase cattle for breeding. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers, as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Donna's Group

texts.en: Donna B. is from the village of Diamantina, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Donna is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Donna is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Donna runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Donna has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Donna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Donna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Donna is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Donna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena S. sells smoked fish, maize and millet in Takoradi. She is divorced and takes care of six dependants. She has been in this business for six years. She sees to the welfare of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy land.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale.

loans.name: Marthe

texts.fr: Marthe est née le 28 Juillet 1987 et est mariée à un mécanicien du nom de Alain. Le couple n'a pas encore d'enfant. Il y a environs huit ans que Marthe s'est installée à Ekpè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, où elle vit avec son mari. Marthe a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Depuis trois ans, Marthe a ouvert un centre de photocopie à Ekpè et y vend également des cartes de recharges téléphonique et des CD ; ce qui lui procure des revenus l'aidant à assurer ses besoins quotidiens. Marthe s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la deuxième fois que Marthe sollicite l'appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. Son premier crédit a été bien remboursé.
texts.en: Marthe was born on 28th July 1987 and is married to a mechanic by the name of Alain. The couple does not yet have any children. Around eight years ago Marthe settled down in Ekpè in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji, where she lives with her husband. She left school at secondary level. Three years ago Marthe set up a photocopying centre in Ekpè and she also sells telephone recharge cards and CDs there; this earns her an income which helps her to cover her daily needs. Marthe gets her supplies at Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. It is the second time that she has asked for financial support from ALIDé in able to boost her business and respond better to customer demand. Her first loan was repaid in full.

loans.use: Purchase of telephone recharge cards, CDs, photocopier ink, boxes of A4 paper

loans.name: Eunice Nyambura

texts.en: Eunice Nyambura is 31 years old and married to Fredrick Mutwiri, who contributes to the family income. They have two children, ages 13 and 2 years old. She has been running a grocery store for a period of two years with an income of about 4,000 Kenyan shillings a month. This is her first loan with KADET and she wants to use it to buy tomatoes and charcoal for resale. She hopes to be a supplier of green vegetables. She wants to give her children a quality education and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes and charcoal

loans.name: Lilibeth's Group

texts.en:
Lilibeth A. is from the village of Union, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Lilibeth is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lilibeth is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lilibeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Lilibeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Maame Esi

texts.en: Maame Esi E. is a fish monger. She also sells charcoal in Takoradi. She is married and has five dependants. Her husband is a farmer. She assists her husband in providing the basic needs of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more fish to smoke for sale. She hopes to reinvest her new profits.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Akutwala Ekiro Nakawuka-Mpigi Group

texts.en: Edith N. is 30 years old and happily married with four children. She is affiliated with the Akutwala Ekiro Nakawuka-Mpigi Group. For the past three years, Edith has been operating a business selling fresh food in Nakawuka. She started small, but her future prospects are looking brighter because her clientele is increasing. Edith has mostly been selling cassava, maize, beans, cabbage and other varieties of food staples that are common among people in her area. She was able to start her business with savings from an earlier job working in a local craft shop. Her food business requires hard work, determination, and constant planning. Edith’s weekly profits are approximately 150,000 UGX. With this loan, Edith will buy more food to sell.

loans.use: to purchase food to sell

loans.name: Sister

texts.en: Sister A. is single and sells foodstuffs such as plantain, cassava and cocoyam. She has been in this trade for five years. Sister is requesting the loan in order to buy more and varied types of food, as requested by her customers. With the new profit from her expanded business, she plans to buy land.

loans.use: Sister is going to use the loan to buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida M. is from the village of Magsaysay. She is 53 years old. Nida is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Nida owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising ducks for breeding and for sale. Nida has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Nida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Nida is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Nida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua A. is married and has four children. Her husband is a driver. She sells smoked fish at Takoradi market. Efua assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Efua will use the loan to buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene M., age 33, runs a salon at Tala market. She is a single mother of one child, Charles Mbithi, who is 10 years old. She has been running this salon for 9 years and her monthly profit is 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). Irene was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Tala office. This loan of 15,000 KES is her first loan with KADET. She intends to use the loan to buy cosmetics, hair relaxers and beauty products. If the loan boosts the business, Irene will pay school fees for her son. Irene dreams of owning a big salon and barber shop. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics, hair relaxers and beauty products

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Elle a en charge 2 enfants et âgée de 40 ans. Elle est  coiffeuse et tresseuse.  Mais elle a associé la vente  des mèches et tissage pour plus de revenus.  Elle cumule 16 ans dans cette activité et achète au grand marché de Lomé. En plus elle satisfait les clients dans son atelier à Adidogomé. Avec ce prêt, elle espère acheter 4 douzaines de mèches, 4 douzaines de tissages et 3 boites de gels.
texts.en: This lady has two children in her care and is 40 years old. She is a hairdresser and a hair weaver. However, she also sells hair extensions and weaves to get more income. She has gathered 16 years of experience in this business and she buys her products at the large market in Lomé. Furthermore, she looks after her customers in her workshop in Adidogomé. With this loan, she is hoping to buy four dozen hair extensions, four dozen weaves and three boxes of gel.

loans.use: Purchase of hair extensions and weaves

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua N. prepares tea and serves it with fried eggs. She also sells soft drinks at Takoradi market. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy additional soft drinks for sale. She plans to reinvest her new profit.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks for sale

loans.name: Benendetah

texts.en:
Benendetah M. is 45 years old and is married to Felix. Together they have a 21-year-old daughter named Victoria. Benendetah runs a photo studio in Kagundo. She has been running this studio for the past 12 years and her monthly income is 15,000 KES.

Benendetah was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Tala office. This loan of 50,000 KES will be her fifth KADET loan and Benendetah will use it to buy digital cameras and frames. Benendetah describes herself as hardworking and she has repaid her previous loans. If this loan boosts her business, she will use the profit to pay school fees for her daughter. In the future, Benendetah dreams of having a big studio.

loans.use: to buy digital cameras and frames

loans.name: Erkul

texts.en:
Erkul M. is 36, married and has two children of school age. He graduated from Kyrgyz Architectural Institute but couldn’t find a well-paid job to cover all the expenses of his young family. In order to find a means of subsistence, Erkul decided to start his own business selling foodstuffs – frozen chicken meat and sausages – at the local market. His start as an entrepreneur was successful due to his great efforts and strong will to provide his children with the essentials. 

Erkul was able to open his own small shop and purchase tracks for products transportation. In June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the Osh city, Erkul lost his business. His sales shop at the market was robbed and looted, and his storage was burned. But Erkul didn’t give up and decided to resume his lost business and continue his activities. For this very reason, Erkul is applying for a loan of 100,000 soms (KGS), which he needs to restart his business. Erkul is a very optimistic and hardworking person who moves his family ahead and makes every effort for it. 

======================================

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase goods for reselling

loans.name: Agness

texts.en: Agness D. is divorced and has one child. Agness sells palm oil, vegetable cooking oil and other foodstuffs at Takoradi market. She takes care of her family with the income she makes from her sales. Agness is asking to use the loan to purchase food items to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agness plans to save towards the education of her child.

loans.use: To purchase food items to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia S., age 35, runs a retail shop in Mukuku, which has many villagers. She is married to Cosmas and together they have two daughters: Winfred and Agnes, ages 20 and 18 years respectively. She has been running her business for two years and her monthly profit is 10,000 Kenyan shillings. Cecilia was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Tala office. This loan of 15,000 KES is her second loan with KADET and she plans to use it to increase stock of sugar, detergents, bread and paraffin for sale. If the loan boosts business, Cecilia will pay school fees and buy food for her children. Cecilia dreams of having a wholesale shop. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To increase stock of sugar, detergents, bread and paraffin for sale

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline S. is from the village of Magsaysay, Naguillan, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Evangeline is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector managing a buy and sell of beddings. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of beddings like pillows, matts, blankets and bedsheets in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Evangeline joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 18000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Evangeline from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ayélé

texts.fr: Ayélé a 2 enfants et est âgée de 33 ans. Pour améliorer les conditions de vie de ses enfants, elle fait la vente de friperies. Elle s’approvisionne au marché hédzranawoé  et revend ensuite au marché Adidogomé. Elle est née à Tabligbo et réside à Adidogomé. Dans cette activité, elle compte 2 ans d’expérience. Elle demande un credit pour acheter 5 bales de friperies.
texts.en: Ayélé has two children and is 33 years old. In order to improve her children's living conditions she sells second-hand clothing. She gets her supplies at the market in Hédzranawoé and then resells them at the market in Adidogomé. She was born in Tabligbo and lives in Adidogomé. She has two years experience in this business. She is asking for a loan to buy five bundles of second-hand clothes.

loans.use: Purchase of second-hand clothing

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy K. is marrried and has two children. Mercy sells onions, as well as and women and children clothing, at Takoradi market.  She has been in this business for two years. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Mercy will use the loan to buy more children and women clothing for resale. She plans to buy a piece of land from her increased capital.

In the picture, on her lap are some clothing on a tray.

loans.use: To buy children and women clothing for resale

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas W., age 33, runs a general open air business in Tala. He is married to Gladys Ndulu, age 30, and they don’t have any children. He has been running his business for two years and his monthly profit is 12,000 Kenyan shillings.
 
Thomas was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Tala office. This loan of 20,000 KES is his first loan with KADET and he intends to use the loan to increase his stock of baby toys, cosmetics, umbrellas, belts and necklaces for resale. If the loan boosts his business, Thomas will add stock to his business and pay school fees for his sisters and brothers. Thomas dreams of having a big shop. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To increase stock of baby toys, cosmetics, umbrellas, belts and necklaces

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred G. is from the village of Magsaysay, Naguillan, Isabela. She is 37 years old. Mildred is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mildred owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector managing a general store business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of products in the community. Mildred has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mildred joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mildred has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Mildred is requesting a new loan of 18000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Mildred from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose W., age 23, is a farmer from Tala. She is married to Elijah Kioko and together they have one son, Mbisi, age 4 years old. Rose has been farming for 3 years and her monthly income is 6,000 Kenyan shillings. She was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients. This loan of 5,500 KES is her first loan with KADET which she intends to use to buy seedlings and fertilizers. If the loan boosts her business, Rose will save some money and expand her farm. Rose describes herself as hardworking and hopes to become a great farmer.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Mawussi

texts.fr: Elle est mariée est  et a 2 enfants en charge. Elle  est  âgée  de 49 ans. Elle fait la vente de pagnes, des ustensiles de cuisine et un peu de produits d’alimentation.  Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé et revend dans une boutique à son domicile. Elle demande un prêt   pour faire face à la demande sans cesse croissante.
texts.en: This lady is married and has two children in her care. She is 49 years old. She sells "pagnes" (pieces of colourful West African fabric), kitchen utensils and a few food products. She gets her supplies at the large market in Lomé and resells them in a shop in her home. She is requesting a loan in order to face ever increasing customer demand.

loans.use: Purchase of "pagnes" and food products

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa A. sells provisions and assorted drinks at Takoradi market. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a photographer. Adwoa has been in this trade for ten years. She assists her husband in feeding, clothing and educating her children. She is requesting this loan to expand her provision business. She hopes to reinvest her new profit.

loans.use: To expand provision business

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan N., age 41, runs a retail shop in Tala. She is married to Pius, age 46, and together they have two children: Felista in class 8 and Felix in class 4. Susan has been running her business for five years and her monthly profit is 13,000 Kenyan shillings. She was introduced to KADET by her friends. This loan of 40,000 KES is her third loan with KADET and she plans to use it to increase her stock of sugar, detergents, bread, bar soaps, sodas and snacks for sale. If the loan boosts her business, Susan will save and make permanent investments. Susan describes herself as a hopeful lady who is ready to better herself. She dreams of having a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To increase stock of sugar, detergents, bar soaps, sodas and snacks

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty G. is currently in the business of charging mobile phones and selling airtime for MTN, Zain, Vivacell, etc.   She is requesting a loan to stock more airtime to sell.  Betty is 22 years old and is married.  Her husband is also in business. She has 1 child who is not in school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock more airtime to sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva T.  is currently in the business of selling sugar, rice, and charging phones.  She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and sugar to sell.  Eva is 20 years old and is married.  Her husband is a driver. She has 1 child.  Her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock more rice and sugar to sell

loans.name: Akossouwa

texts.fr: Akossiwa is 50 years old and has three children. She is married to a retailer. In order to make a contribution to the household, she sells sundries (food products, kitchen utensils, beauty products and colorful African cloth). She already has 20 years experience in this business. She gets her supplies at the large market in Lomé and resells at her home. She is requesting a loan in order to increase her business and make a significant profit.
texts.en: Akossiwa is 50 years old and has three children. She is married to a retailer. In order to make a contribution to the household, she sells sundries (food products, kitchen utensils, beauty products and colorful African cloth). She already has 20 years experience in this business. She gets her supplies at the large market in Lomé and resells at her home. She is requesting a loan in order to increase her business and make a significant profit.

loans.use: Purchase of food products and kitchen utensils

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 37-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is the mother of three school-age children. She has been working as a private nurse for the past 10 years. She has obtained a previous Kiva loan to purchase a car in order to facilitate her business movements. And she is thankful for the results. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to pay for her children's school fees.
