María hopes to stock more beer to meet her customers' demand during this time of year.  This is why she decided to request a loan of 1,500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to stock more beer to meet her customers' demand

loans.name: Santos Marcelino

texts.es:
Santos es un padre de familia de 53 años de edad que reside junto a su esposa y a sus hijos en el sector San Martín del distrito de Lambayeque, una zona comercial que se encuentra ubicada a más de veinte minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace más de diez años a la venta ambulante de productos de uso personal como por ejemplo cortaúñas. Tijeras, pinzas, hisopos, lentes, medias, limas de uñas, entre otros. El ofrece su mercadería en los principales terminales terrestres de la ciudad de Chiclayo y adicionalmente viaja a los pueblos aledaños durante las diversas festividades que se realizan. Su esposa cuenta con una pequeña bodega y con lo que ambos ganan se encarga de sacar adelante la economía de su familia.

Santos desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más productos de modo que pueda aumentar sus ventas y percibir mayores ganancias. Para lograr su objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 600 nuevos soles.
texts.en: Santos is a 53 year-old father who lives with his wife and their children in the San Martín area of Lambayeque district, a commercial zone located just over 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For over ten years, he has been an itinerant vendor of personal use products like nail clippers, scissors, tweezers, cotton swabs, sunglasses, tights, nail files, and other items. He sells his merchandise on the main pedestrian streets of Chiclayo and also travels to outlying villages during their various festivals. His wife has a small bodega [grocery store] and with both of their earnings they are able to improve their family's economic situation. Santos would like to expand his business by buying more popular items so that he can increase his sales and bring in more profits. This is why he decided to request a loan of 600 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to buy more products to increase his sales and earn more profit

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa tiene 67 años D. edad, es viuda y resiD. junto a uno D. sus hijos y a una cuñada en el distrito D. Jayanca, una zona agrícola que se encuentra situada en la provincia D. Lambayeque, a más D. una hora D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo.

Se dedica desD. hace más D. veinte años a la venta D. artículos para celebración D. fiestas infantiles (piñatería) para lo cual cuenta con un establecimiento instalado en su domicilio. Adicionalmente alquila sillas y toldos para dichas actividades. Este negocio le permite ayudar al sostenimiento económico D. su familia.

Teresa desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo más mercadería, con esta inversión ella espera satisfacer la demanda con la que cuenta y seguir progresando. Para lograr su objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad D. solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 2000 nuevos soles.
texts.en: Teresa is 67 years old, widowed, and lives with her children and a sister-in-law in Jayanca district, an agricultura zone located in Lambayeque province, more than an hour from the city of Chiclayo. She has been selling supplies for children's parties (piñatería) for over 20 years. Her business is set up in her house. She also rents chairs and tents for parties. This business allows her to help meet her family's economic needs. Teresa would like to expand her business by acquiring more merchandise. She hopes that, with this investment, she will be able to meet her customers' demand, which has consistently been increasing. In order to achieve her goal, she decided to request a loan of 2,000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to expand her business with more merchandise

loans.name: Eliana Abigail

texts.es:
Eliana tiene 28 años de edad, es soltera y reside junto a su familia en el distrito de Olmos, una zona agrícola de bastante movimiento comercial que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora y cuarenta y cinco minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella es maestra de profesión y actualmente trabaja en una institución educativa de su localidad, adicionalmente prepara todo tipo de postres, dulces y bocaditos, los cuales prepara por pedido para las festividades y eventos especiales. Ella gusta mucho de estas dos actividades y con los ingresos que percibe se encarga de colaborar con la economía de su familia.

Eliana desea completar el dinero que necesita para adquirir una laptop que le permita preparar un mejor material educativo para sus alumnos, por ello se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Eliana is 28 years old, she's single and lives with her family in the Olmos district, an agricultural zone with a lot of commercial movement located in the province of Lambayeque more than an hour and forty-five minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

She is a teacher by profession and currently works in an educational institution in her community. Moreover, she prepares on order all types of desserts, sweets, and snacks for festivities and special events. She really enjoys these two activities and with the income she receives she takes on the responsibility of participating in the family finances.

Eliana would like to get together the money necessary to acquire a laptop which will allow her to prepare better educational material for her students. For this reason she has seen it necessary to request Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 1000 soles.

loans.use: Acquire a laptop which will allow her to prepare better educational material for her students.

loans.name: Victoria Aracely

texts.es:
Victoria tiene 19 años de edad, es soltera y reside junto a sus padres en el distrito de Olmos, una zona agrícola de bastante movimiento comercial que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora y cuarenta minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la venta de  abarrotes, productos comestibles, golosinas y bebidas, para lo cual posee una bodega, la cual funciona en su domicilio. Este negocio es de mucha utilidad para la economía de su familia por lo que Victoria siempre trata de mantenerlo del mejor modo posible.

Ella desea comprar abarrotes para satisfacer la demanda que suele aumentar debido a la campaña navideña y de año nuevo. Para lograr su objetivo ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Victoria is 19 years old, she is single and lives with her parents in the Olmos district, an agricultural zone with a lot of commercial movement located in the province of Lambayeque more than an hour and forty-five minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

She sells groceries, foodstuffs, candy, and drinks for which she runs a grocery store from her house. This business is very useful for the family finances and for this reason Victoria always trys to maintain it in the best way possible.

She would like to buy groceries to satisfy the demand which usually increases due to the Christmas season and New Years. In order to achieve her objective, she believed it to be advisable to request Edpyme Alternative for a loan of 500 soles.

loans.use: To buy groceries to satisfy the demand.

loans.name: Faten

texts.en: Faten S. and her husband have an olive wood workshop producing all-wood handicrafts such as crosses, statues, necklaces, etc. Faten has one daughter and three sons who are all school students. Faten and her husband work in the workshop together. Faten took out a loan to purchase work tools and to pay for printing business cards. As Christmas is around the corner, the workshop's clients are demanding more products, as well as the tourists who come to buy Christmas wooden ornaments and souvenirs. Faten has had five loans before this one from FATEN and has always committed to repayments. Faten's picture was taken in FATEN's office.

loans.use: To purchase olive wood and business cards

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy some modern photography equipment.

loans.name: Najeh

texts.en:
Najeh is a well known owner of a grocery shop in Nablus city where he sells many items as well as fruits and vegetables. Najeh is the father of four daughters and two sons who are all either school or college students. He also owns some land where he grows different kinds of crops according to the seasons as a second source of income. Najeh has been in his business for eight years and has established a good reputation in the city.

Najeh came to FATEN to take out a loan to make repairs that the store needs such as painting, replacing the shelves, etc. Najeh appears in the picture in his store.

loans.use: To do repairs at the grocery store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more shoes for his shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tools for his workshop

loans.name: Rabeeha

texts.en:
Rabeeha, who is the mother of three daughters and three sons, is a teacher at the UNRWA schools. Rabeeha's husband passed away and she became responsible for raising the children. Teaching wasn't enough to support her big family; therefore, she started making embroideries and selling them. Rabeeha has been producing embroideries for six years now. She started producing orders for families and some associations in Hebron. Rabeeha has an order to start and she needs to buy fabric and thread to start the production. Therefore, she came to FATEN and took out a $500 loan.

Rabeeha sits in the FATEN office in Hebron in the picture here.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and thread for embroidery

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase goods for the store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To build two new rooms in their house.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua N. is married. Her husband is a technician.  Efua sells charcoal and fruits at Takoradi, which she has been doing for two years. Efua also assists her husband in the general upkeep of their home.

She is seeking a loan to purchase more charcoal for resale. With the new profits she expects from this expansion, Efua plans to reinvest back into the business.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther N., who is married to a security man and has three children, has been been selling frozen meat and salted fish in Takoradi for six years. She uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Esther will add the loan to her income to expand her fish business, and plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded operation back into her enterprise.

The photo shows Esther cutting the salted fish into pieces for sale.

loans.use: Esther will add the loan to her income to expand her fish business.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba A. sells smoked and fried fish at Takoradi.  She is married and has seven dependents. Her husband is a farmer.

Aba has been selling fish for quite some time now. She assists in the upkeep of her family's home from the income she generates from her sales.  She intends to use this loan to expand her fish business.  If she is able to make more profit, she anticipates using it help pay for her dependents' education.

Aba was in the process of frying some fish when the picture that accompanies this profile was taken.

loans.use: to expand a fish business.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. sells cooked rice at Takoradi. She is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a farmer.  Ama assists her husband in providing for the basic needs of the family, such as food, clothing and shelter.

Ama plans to use the proceeds from this loan  to buy rice and other ingredients to expand her business. She hopes to use any increased profits from her business to build a better place for her customers to sit to eat.

loans.use: to buy rice and other ingredients for a stall that sells cooked food

loans.name: Naana

texts.en:
Naana N. is married and has two children. She has received a junior high education. Her husband is a mason.  She assists her husband in taking care of their home.

Naana sells and corn dough at Takoradi.  Corn and cassava dough are used to prepare a favorite Ghanaian dish called "Banku." She has been in this trade for fifteen years.  Naana plans to use this loan to expand her business by increasing the volume of corn and cassava dough she makes.  If she is able to generate additional income as a result, she wishes to use the extra money to buy land.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Nana stands with bagged corn and cassava dough she sells.

loans.use: to expand a corn and cassava dough making business

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame A. is divorced. She sells food and fresh produce such as garden eggs (also known as Ethiopian eggplant), tomatoes, and onions at Takoradi.

Maame plans to use the proceeds of this loan to buy more vegetables and fruit to sell in order to be able to meet the demands of her customers.  If she generates additional profit as a result of this loan, she plans to reinvest it back into her business.

loans.use: to buy more fruit, vegetables, and other food to resell at market

loans.name: Maame Ama

texts.en:
Maame Ama P. is divorced and has one child. She operates a provision shop at Takoradi.  Maame uses her income to see to the well being of her family. 

Maame will use the proceeds of this loan to purchase more provisions to expand her business. If she is able to generate additional profit from her business, she plans to save it, and then invest it by opening another shop at a different locality

loans.use: to purchase more provisions to expand a small grocery store

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica E. is married and has one child. Her husband is a cook at a nearby village restaurant. Veronica sells groceries at Takoradi and uses income from her sales to assist her husband in supporting the general well-being of their home.

Veronica's grocery shop is a year old and she plans to use the proceeds of this loan to expand it.  If her profits increase, she plans to reinvest the additional income back into her business.

loans.use: to expand a grocery shop

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa B. sells secondhand clothing and yam at Takoradi. She is married, has one child, and her husband is a driver. She has been in this business for seven years, and uses her income to help her husband in the general upkeep of their home.

Yaa plans to use this loan to buy more yam to resell, with the hope of expanding her business.  If she makes additional profit as a result, she says she will reinvest it back into her business.

loans.use: to buy more yam to resell

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua E. sells cassava, yam, plantain and other food items at Takoradi.  She has been doing this for ten years.  Efua is married to a sand and gravel supplier.  She uses her income to assist her husband in providing the for the basic needs of their family.

Efua will use the proceeds of this loan to acquire more food items to sell. If she makes any additional profit as a result of this loan, she intends to save it and buy some land.

loans.use: to buy food items to resell

loans.name: Naana

texts.en:
Naana N. sells cassava and shoes at Takoradi. She has been in this business for ten years now. Naana, who is divorced, uses income from the sale of her goods to rent a house and to pay utility bills.

Naana plans to use her loan to buy a variety of food items for resale. She plans to reinvest any additional profit she makes back into her business.

loans.use: to buy food items for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his brother's wedding party

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. sells firewood and fante kenkey in Takoradi. This divorced mother, who lives with her five dependents, sees responsibly to the well-being of her family. Her loan will be used to buy more maize to prepare the kenkey for sale, and she hopes to build a shop from the new profit.

In this photo, Ama is displaying some fante kenkeys. The pan on her right has gari which she sells. On her left is an ice chest containing bags of water to sell to thirsty passersby.

loans.use: To buy more maize to prepare the kenkey for sale.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa K., who sells both cooked and raw rice in Takoradi, assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more bags of rice to cook for sale and to sell as raw rice. She anticipates using the new profits from her business to save towards the education of her children.

At the time this photo was taken, Adwoa had not yet cooked the rice for her afternoon customers.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice to cook for sale and to sell as raw rice.

loans.name: Rabie

texts.en:
Rabie is the father of seven children: three daughters and four sons, who are all students. Rabie inherited his shop from his father and has been running it for five years now. He started work with his father at a young age and gained good experience dealing with customers.

Rabie came to FATEN and asked for a loan to improve the shop and add more shelves. Rabie appears in the picture here in front of his store.

loans.use: To improve a car accessories store

loans.name: Atta

texts.en:
Atta B. is married to a mason. She sells fresh and smoked fish at Takoradi and has been doing this for five years. She assists her husband to take care of  the home. 

Her loan will be used to buy additional fish for sale to expand her business. She hopes to reinvest her additional capital.
In this photo, Atta is cleaning the fish to be smoked.

loans.use: To buy additional fish for sale

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame N. is married and has three children. Her husband is a farmer. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. 

Maame sells clothes and shoes at Takoradi. The loan she is requesting will be added to her capital to buy varieties of shoes to meet the demands of her customers. She wishes to build a shop with her additional capital.

loans.use: To buy varieties of shoes for sale

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice C. is married to a security man. She takes care of six dependents. 

Beatrice sells food items at Takoradi. She has been in this business for four years. Beatrice uses her income to assist her husband in the general upkeep of their home. 

Beatrice will use the loan to purchase more food items for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Beatrice plans to save in order to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: To purchase more food items for sale

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame D. is divorced and takes care of two children. She is responsible for the well-being of her family. 

She sells cassava, tomatoes and other provisions at Takoradi. She started this business not long ago. Her loan will be used to buy varieties of food items to expand her business. She plans to reinvest her additional income back into her business.

loans.use: To buy varieties of food items to expand her business

loans.name: Rukaya

texts.en:
Rukaya H. is married and has one child. Her husband is a driver. She assists her husband in feeding, clothing and educating her  child.

Rukaya sells jewelries and fabrics in the vicinity of Takoradi by moving from one area to another. She is asking for the loan so she can buy more fabrics to sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profit.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics to sell

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame M. is married and has four children. Her husband is a corn miller. She sells provisions at Takoradi, which she has been doing for fifteen years.  Maame uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of their children's school fees and household expenses such as utility bills.

Maame plans to use this loan to purchase additional provisions to expand her business.  Maame plans to save any additional profits she makes from her business in order to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase additional provisions for a grocery store

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua Y. sells plantain and cassava at Takoradi. She is divorced, lives together with her three children, and is responsible for the well-being of her home.  Ekua plans to use the money from this loan to buy foodstuffs to resell. She plans to reinvest any profit she makes back into her business.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Ekua is pictured with cassava that she sells.

loans.use: to buy a variety of foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi A. sells coconut and palm fruit at Takoradi and has been in this trade for ten years.  She is married to a street cleaner and has four children.  Esi assists her husband in feeding, clothing and educating their children.

Esi plans to use this loan to buy palm fruit and dried coconut to resell. If she is able to make more profit, she will use it to further her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy palm fruit and dried coconut

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa N. sells bags of charcoal at Takoradi.  She is married and lives together with her five dependents. Her husband is a palm wine tapper.  Adwoa uses her income to assist her husband in the general upkeep of their home.

Adwoa plans to use this loan to buy extra bags of charcoal for sale.  She hopes to use any additional profit she makes to build a storeroom for the charcoal.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Adwoa stands beside a few bags of charcoal.

loans.use: to purchase extra bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Yaako Efua

texts.en:
Yaako Efua E. is divorced, has five dependents, and is responsible for the well-being of her home. She sells drinks and foodstuffs such as cassava, plantain, and yam at Takoradi.  She has been doing this for three years.

Yaako plans to use the proceeds of this loan to purchase more foodstuffs for resale.  If she is able to generate new profits as a result of expanding her business, Yaako intends to use the additional income to pay for her dependents' education.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Yaako is pictured with cassava in a basket.

loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase more food stuffs for resale

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana S. is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a farmer.  

Nana attended school through junior high.  Now she sells charcoal and rice at Takoradi.  Demand for her goods is high and she is looking to expand her business by buying more bags of charcoal to sell. Currently, she uses her income to assist her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. She plans to use the additional income to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to resell

loans.name: Akoua

texts.en:
Akoua M. cooks and sells kenkey, a dish that is similar to a sourdough dumpling.  Kenkey is made from fermented corn.  Akoua is divorced and has five dependents, and she sees to the well-being of her home.

Akoua has been selling kenkey in Takoradi for some time now.  Her loan will be used to buy more maize to prepare kenkey for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her dependents.

In this photo,  Akoua has not yet prepared kenkey for the day. She is showing the pot she uses for cooking.

loans.use: To buy more maize to prepare food

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama T. is married and has five dependents. She pursued her education through senior high school. Ama sells cooked rice in Takoradi, which she has been doing for 15 years. Her husband is a street cleaner. She assists her husband in providing for the family's basic needs. 

Ama plans to use the loan to purchase more rice to cook and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to educate her dependents.

loans.use: To purchase more rice to cook and sell

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad is a barber from the village of Roujeb, next to Nablus city. He started this work five years ago after he completed the necessary training courses. Muhammad's shop is one of the oldest in the village where he lives. Muhammad came to FATEN and took out a loan to improve the shop by painting the walls and purchasing needed tools and chairs for the shop.

Muhammad appears in the picture here cutting one of his customer's hair.

loans.use: To paint the shop and purchase tools and chairs

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa M. is divorced and has  two children. She pursued her education through senior high school.  Adwoa sells clothes in Takoradi. She has been in this trade for some time now, and she uses her income to improve to the welfare of her family's home.  

Adwoa will use the loan to purchase more clothes for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adwoa plans to save to build a shop.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to resell

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena A. sells smoked fish, fried fish and fante kenkey, a food staple made from fermented maize dough wrapped in leaves.  Abena has been educated through junior high school.  She is married and has four children. Her husband taps palm trees for palm wine to make a living, and Abena assists her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. 

She sells her goods in Takoradi and demand is high.  Abena is looking to expand her business to increase her profit. She wishes to increase production and sales, so she is asking for a loan to buy fish to fry and maize to prepare fante kenkey for sale.

By Abena's left hand, a row of fante kenkey is visible.  On her right side, there is a wooden tray with fried fish arranged for sale.

loans.use: To buy fish and maize.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa B. sells bags of cement used for construction.  She is married to a plumber and together they live with their three children. Adwoa, who has completed senior high school, assists her husband financially to support the needs of their family.

Adwoa intends to use the proceeds of this loan to buy more bags of cement. If she is able to expand her business and generate more profit,  she plans to use the extra income to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: to buy more bags of cement

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A.  is married and has three children.  Her husband is a land surveyor.  Efua, a junior high graduate, sells tomatoes, pepper and other food items at Takoradi.  She uses her income to assist her husband in providing for the basic needs of their family.

Efua intends to use this loan to purchase food items which are often requested by her customers.  She plans to reinvest any new profits she makes back into her business so she can expand her operations.

loans.use: to buy food items such as tomato and pepper for resale

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha Q. sells provisions at Takoradi. She is married to a driver and together they live with their four children. Martha has been selling provisions for ten years and uses her income to assist her husband in paying for the education her children.

Martha hopes this loan will enable her to expand her grocery business. If she is able to increase her income as a result of this loan, she plans save money in order to buy land.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a grocery business

loans.name: Mena

texts.en: Mena E. is married and has two children. She has completed her high school education. Mena sells cassava and plantain at Takoradi. Her husband is a mason. Mena assists her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. Demand for her goods is high and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profit. She is asking for the loan to buy more foodstuffs for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mena plans to increase her sales. In the photo above, Mena is selling only cassava because the plantain crop was finished.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida B. is married and has five dependants. Her husband is a plumber. She has completed junior high school. Vida sells bags of charcoal at Takoradi, which she has been doing for six years. Vida uses her income to assist her husband in educating her children. Vida will use the loan to purchase more charcoal in order to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Vida plans to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa B. sells maize and porridge at Takoradi. She is married and has five dependants. Her husband is a driver. She assists her husband in providing the basic needs for their family. Demand for her goods is high and she is looking to expand her business by preparing porridge in larger quantities. She hopes to increase her production with the new profit. She also wants to revive her maize business. She is asking for a loan to purchase more maize. Some of the maize she will sell, and some she will use to prepare a popular Ghanaian breakfast called 'kooko,' which she will sell. In the picture above, she is showing the pot she uses to prepare the porridge.

loans.use: To purchase maize

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a massage machine

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is a widow with a teenage son. Natalya lives in Novomoskovsk. She is a market vendor selling boots, galoshes, rubber boots and valenki (felt boots). Natalya owns a kiosk in the central marketplace of her home town. She has been in this business for 10 years. Her investment in inventory amounts to 56,000 Grivnyas. Net profit is about 7,000 Grivnyas a month.  

Natalya is seeking a loan of 11,700 Grivnyas to purchase winter merchandise. She is hoping to attract new customers with additional merchandise. Eventually she hopes to save enough to help her son through college. Her son lives with her at the moment. Natalya is the only breadwinner in her family.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda is married with two children. She is a entrepreneur from Novomoskovsk. Nadezhda runs a small clothing sales business. She sells men’s and women’s knitted wear in the central marketplace of her home town. Nadezhda has been working in this business for 5 years. She has invested 40,000 Grivnyas in merchandise. Her net profit amounts to 5,500 Grivnyas a month. 

Nadezhda is requesting a loan of 11,700 Grivnyas to purchase seasonal merchandise. Warm winter clothing always sells better in the cold season. Nadezhda is expecting a usual increase in customer demand and better sales as a result. One of her long-term business plans is to purchase a vehicle for business purposes.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is divorced. She has a grown son who is married. Her son and daughter-in-law live with her. Valentina is a tomato farmer with five big greenhouses. Last year she planted 15,000 short-growing tomatoes. Valentina is a veteran in the sphere of agriculture – she has been working in farming and gardening for about 32 years. She has already invested 70,000 Grivnyas in her business. 

Valentina is seeking a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to purchase polyethylene film, seeds and fertilizers for her greenhouses. Valentina is planning to plant 10,000 tall-growing tomatoes this farming season. These tomatoes grow and produce fruit for a long time until the frost comes in the fall. One of her further plans is to continue expanding and construct another greenhouse for tomatoes in the future.

loans.use: To purchase polyethylene film, seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is married with two children. She is a market entrepreneur from Belaya Tserkov. Alla sells meat, such as chicken meat, fillets, wings, sausage, etc. She owns two vending locations that basically don’t have any competition. Alla used to sell chicken meat only. However, recently she started selling sausages, too. Alla has been working in this sphere of vending for two years. Her income exceeds 7,000 Grivnyas a month.  

Alla is seeking a 15,000 Grivnya loan to purchase a self-contained refrigerator display for a new vending facility. Alla is planning to open her third meat vending kiosk. She needs to equip it with a refrigerator display and stock it with merchandise. Alla believes a good quality refrigerator will keep all her meat fresh and a nice display of meat merchandise will attract potential customers to her kiosk.  One of Alla’s long-term plans is to expand her business and eventually have her own retail chain.

loans.use: To purchase a self-contained refrigerator display

loans.name: Evgeniya

texts.en:
Evgeniya is married with one son. She sells women’s purses and tights at the city market in Novaya Kahovka. Evgeniya has been in this business for six years and her current monthly profit is 5,000 UAH. 

Evgeniya is requesting a loan of 12,200 UAH to further develop her business and increase the assortment of her inventory. She hopes to use her increased income to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married with two adult sons. She rents space at a small store where she sells clothing. Olga started her business 15 years ago and has been developing and improving it since then. Olga enjoys her business and would like to further expand. 

Olga is requesting a loan of 15,000 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventory. She has used business loans before and found them very helpful. Olga hopes to increase her sales to make additional profit.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina, who is married with one child, runs a small store selling cups, dishes, clattery and other kitchen items. In this business for two years now and with a monthly profit of 4,000 Grivnas, Irina’s enthusiasm and determination to succeed helps her in her daily work.

Hoping to increase her sales and income during winter holidays, Irina is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnas to purchase more inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David N. is an individual client from Kyenjojo. He is 42 years old and married and he his 6 children, 4 of whom are still in school. 

David is a farmer who grows and sells produce, such as Irish potatoes, beans, maize, and matooke (green plantains).  He also buys produce from other farmers in the Katareiha area. His customers are daily transporters from different towns and he is able to make 30,000/= (Kenyan shillings) in profit each week. David is also involved in music production; all self initiated and motivated businesses. 

David needs a loan to be able to purchase more produce to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more produce to sell

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis K. is an individual client from Kyenjojo. He is 34 years old and married, and he has 6 children. He is a very hard-working man. He has a business selling produce and making and selling waragi, a local brew from Kijugu. He has been in this business for 12 years and he is able to make 1,400,000/= (Kenyan shillings) in profits each week. 

He sells mostly to bars, grocers, and individuals. He started this business because he believed it was profitable and, indeed, it is. His future plan is to continue selling produce and waragi and to open a big store in Kyenjojo. So far, he has bought plots of land as one of his properties.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for making waragi, a local brew.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase produce

loans.name: Kafundezi Basubuuzi Twegatte Group

texts.en: F. Bosco is the leader of Kafundesi group in Mubende. He is 26 years old and married with two children. For the past four years, he has owned a business in Lwanajo Kafundesi selling produce. He is able to make 100,000 UGX in monthly profits by selling to his loyal customers. Bosco says that he was a boda boda cyclist (bicycle taxi driver) before getting into the produce business. He was inspired to make the change by his friends, and he does not regret his decision. He is a hard-working man who needs a loan to be able to buy more matooke, cassava, and sweet potatoes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase matooke, cassava and sweet potatoes for resale

loans.name: Kigarama Tukore Group

texts.en: T. Salvan is the leader of Kigarama Tukore group in Kihihi. He is 34 years old and married with four children. Three of them are in school, while the fourth is still a baby. For the past seven years, he has owned a business selling produce from Kigarama Ntungamo cell. He got into this business by selling his personal harvest as a farmer. He began buying produce from other farmers to sell and found that he could earn more. He is a patient man and very hard-working. This is his first loan from Pearl microfinance. He hopes to develop his business like others who he has seen borrowing from Pearl. He will use the loan to buy beans, cassava, and matooke for resale.

loans.use: To buy beans, cassava, and matooke

loans.name: Shirine

texts.en:
Shirine is the mother of two daughters living in Rafah city in Gaza Strip. Shirine's husband, Shawqi, is a taxi driver who works on transportation lines between Rafah and neighboring cities. Shirine's husband wants to do regular maintenance and paint the car. The maintenance will improve the car's performance and make better returns.

Shirine's husband wishes to be able to save money and take another loan from FATEN to buy a better car in the near future. Shirine's husband appears in the picture here as she is not comfortable with having her picture published online as she comes from a religious family.

loans.use: To paint and fix a taxi car

loans.name: Amer

texts.en:
Amer is a 32-year-old man. Amer is the father of one daughter and three sons. He rented a space less than one year ago to start a grocery store where he sells all food varieties and frozen meat. The store is located next to a school and in a good location in the city. Amer hopes to be able to sell fruits and vegetables soon when the store's returns increase.

Amer came to FATEN and took out a loan to purchase a large variety of goods. The picture of Amer here was taken in the store.

loans.use: To purchase goods to sell in the store

loans.name: Ieng Sinat's Group

texts.en:
This group loan from Boeng Tumnob village, Takeo province, has four members.  Mrs. Ieng S. is the group leader. Their portions of the loan will be used to help their businesses and this can improve the lives of their families.   

Mrs. Ieng S. is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family.  Her husband, Mr. Vat Horng, is a mirror cutter in Thailand. She has problems in the rice field because her field has a lot of insects. So, to improve production, Mrs. Ieng S. is applying for a loan to buy pesticide. 

She is the mother of three children, one of whom is a laborer while the others are studying in public school.

loans.use: To buy pesticide

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Madres Ladereñas Group

texts.es:
Sonia vive en Puente Piedra un lugar D. lima con gente muy trabajadora y emprendedora como ella, casada y con 3 hijos que aun son pequeños siempre busco la manera D. apoyar a su esposo, por  un tiempo vendió jugos en el centro D. la ciudad pero a pesar que el negocio era bueno  la distancia fue un impedimento por que sus  hijos se quedaban solos por  mucho tiempo, fue por esto que junto a su esposo decidieron poner una bodega en su misma casa, su negocio recién esta surgiendo lo que mas venD. son frutas D. la estación y dulces como galletas,biscochos,chocolates y gaseosas, la venta es muy buena sobretodo en temporada escolar debido a que su bodega esta junto a un colegio D. niños,  con su trabajo ha podido ayudar a su hija para que pueda seguir estudios superiores D. computación e informática, por otro lado ya le falta poco para terminar algunos acabados D. lo que será un local mas granD. para su negocio, su préstamo actual lo usara para la compra D. gaseosas y muchas golosinas ella es la secretaria del grupo “MADRES LADEREÑAS” . 

  * Sonia es la tercera D. las sentadas.
texts.en:
Sonia lives in Puente Piedra, an area of Lima with hard-working and enterprising people like her. She is married with 3 young children. She is always looking for a way to support her husband. For some time, she sold juice in the center of the city, but because this business was far, her children stayed by themselves a lot. As a result, she and her husband decided to start a general store in their house. Recently, her business was growing, and she mostly sold seasonal fruit and sweets, including cookies, sponge cakes, chocolates, and sodas. Her business does best during the school year because her store is near a high school. With her business, she has been able to help her daughter so that she can continue studying computers and informatics. On the other hand, she still lacks a little bit to complete a larger location for her business. Her current loan will be usd to buy sodas and more sweets. She is the secretary of the “MADRES LADEREÑAS” group.

*Sonia is the third of the seating women

loans.use: To buy sodas, cookies, and sweets for her store

loans.name: Wafa

texts.en: Wafa is a single woman from Rafah City in Gaza Strip. Wafa rented a store eight years ago and started her own grocery business that she runs with the help of her brother who appears in the picture here. Wafa is a conservative woman and doesn't want her picture online. Wafa wanted to increase the variety of goods she sells in the store. Therefore,  she came to FATEN and took a loan for this purpose. Wafa wishes to have a big supermarket in the near future using savings from the store's profits and the help of FATEN loans.

loans.use: To purchase a larger variety of goods

loans.name: Mrs. Koem Ry Village Bank Group

texts.en:
There are 19 people in this village bank loan group. They live in Prambei Mom Village in Takeo Province. They have selected Mrs. Koem R. to be the village bank present. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes, but all hope to improve their family's living conditions.

Mrs. Koem R. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she grows rice to support her family. Aside from farming, she does not have anything to do to earn money. So to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Koem R. is applying for a loan to buy a cow so she can start a new breeding business. 

Mrs. Koem R. is a widow with two children. One of her children is a laborer and the other is a student.

loans.use: To buy a cow to breed

loans.name: Wael

texts.en:
Wael is the father of one daughter and three sons. He has taken loans from FATEN many times when he has an emergency or a family occasion. Wael took out a loan this time to pay for his young son's medical expenses, as the son's medical expenses are higher than Wael can afford.

Wael has always been a committed client of FATEN. He appears in the picture here in FATEN with Hussam - a loan officer working with FATEN.

loans.use: To pay for a son's medical expenses

loans.name: Subhi

texts.en: Subhi is a taxi driver from Hebron city. Subhi transports passengers inside Hebron and rarely outside the city. He came to FATEN to take out a loan to pay for car insurance fees, as well as perform the regular car check to make sure everything is working fine. Subhi is married and the father of two daughters and three sons. Subhi appears in the picture here in FATEN's office.

loans.use: To pay for car insurance fees

loans.name: Mr. Samat Nget Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty people are members of a village bank loan group located in Pump Edth Village, in Takeo Province. Mr. Samat N. was selected by the other members to be the village bank president. Each member of the group will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose, but all hope to improve their families' living standards.

Mr. Samat N. is a village chief. He is a cow middleman (a broker between farmers and wholesalers) who earns money to support his family. He is the father of two children, a farmer and a student. His wife, Mrs. Lorn Chan, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) plot of land. She grows and sells rice to support her family. Although they try to work hard, they earn little income. So to improve their family's living conditions, Mr. Samat N. is seeking a loan to buy three piglets and pig food to start a new pig-breeding business.

loans.use: To buy three piglets and pig food

loans.name: El Algodonal Florece Group

texts.es:
MATIZADOS OMAR” así se llama el negocio D. la señora Rosa  le puso ese nombre por  su hijo mayor, ella es miembro del grupo “EL ALGODONAL FLORECE” que esta integrado por 12 miembros es uno D. los grupos mas grandes y entusiastas D. EDAPROSPO, el esposo D. Rosa trabaja en una fabrica D. pinturas y por ser empleado le ofrecían las pinturas a crédito y menor costo fue así que juntos decidieron empezar el negocio D. matizados y venta D. pinturas en general, abrieron su negocio en un pequeño puesto D.  un mercado D. la zona posteriormente al crecer la demanda D. pinturas tuvieron que buscar un local mas granD. fue así que encontraron un lugar mas céntrico en la ciudad, donD. le va muy bien, rosa es la que se encarga D. la tienda ella la administra y se dedica por completo a ella, su meta mas próxima es juntar mas dinero para lograr comprarse la tienda que por ahora alquila, lo que hará con el dinero D. su préstamo es comprar mas pinturas ya que comprando por cantidad le sale a menor costo.

*Rosa ValverD. es la cuarta D. la derecha D. las sentadas viste polo negro y pantalon jean,tambien esta en la foto el Sr. Cano como invitado.
texts.en:
“Matizados Omar” is the business owned by Sra. Rosa that is named after her oldest son. She is a member of the group “El Algodonal Florece” (The Cotton Blossom), which consists of twelve members and is one of the largest and most enthusiastic of EDAPROSPO. Rosa’s husband is an employee at a paint factory and sells paint on credit and at low cost. Together they opened their business from a small stand at the local market. Eventually the demand for paint grew, so they had to find a larger location in a more centralized part of the city and have done very well.

Rosa is in charge of managing and perfecting the business. Her goal later on is to have more money so that she can buy a store because she currently rents her location. With the money from this loan, she will buy more paints in bulk in order to get them at lower cost.

*Rosa ValverD. is seated fourth from the right, wearing a black polo shirt and jeans. Also pictured is Sr. Cano, who is a guest.

loans.use: Purchase paints in bulk

loans.name: Mrs. Pheng Srey Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Pump Edth Village, Takeo Province fifteen people have come together to form a village bank. Mrs. Pheng S. has been selected by the other members to be the village bank president. Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose, but all hope to improve their family's living standards.

Mrs. Pheng S. is a farmer who owns small piece of land. She grows and sells rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sey Duch, is a fisherman and construction worker who earns some money to support his family. 

It is time to grow rice in her rice field, but Mrs. Pheng S. did not have enough money, so, to improve production, she is asking for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticide. She has two children, all of whom are students.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticide

loans.name: Yaser

texts.en:
Yaser is a 36-year-old father of three daughters and two sons. He has a grocery store in the city and also works in the sheep trade. Yaser was a construction worker but changed his job a year and a half ago as he had an accident which prevented him from working in construction. He took a loan from FATEN to increase the variety he sells in the grocery store, which will increase the number of clients and profits. 

Yaser appears in the picture above in his store.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods to sell in his store

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed is a photographer and inherited a studio from his father. Ahmed is a father of one daughter and one son. He is a professional photographer who had taken advanced courses in editing. His unique skills attract a good number of clients.

Ahmed wants to buy a new professional camera with the help of a loan he took from FATEN. Ahmed is known for the great quality of his work, time and respect.

Ahmed is pictured here standing in his studio.

loans.use: To purchase a professional camera

loans.name: Enhbat

texts.en:
Enhbat S. is 36 years old. He lives with his wife and four children in the Hovd Province of Western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All four of his children attend the local school. 

Enhbat operates a construction business that specializes in interior and exterior decoration of buildings. His wife is an assistant to him in his business. He has owned this business for almost 10 years and, over this long time, he has earned a good reputation among his customers because of the quality of his work and service. Enhbat, a modest and hardworking man, says, “My only wish is to establish my own construction decoration company in the future.”

He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase equipment, such as a compressor and drill, for his construction business.

loans.use: To purchase necessary equipment, such as a compressor and drill

loans.name: Horoljav

texts.en:
Horoljav D. is 66 year old, She lives with her son in Hovd Province in Mongolia. She and her son live in a ger, a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

Horoljav operates a retail clothing business at the local market. She started her business in 2008 and has since built a stable operation. Her son helps her with the business. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and increase her product line in order to attract more customers. She is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase more winter clothes to sell at her stall.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothes

loans.name: El Bello Amanecer Group

texts.es:
Para Yolanda tener una buena sazón para preparar las comidas fue el primer motivo por lo cual decidió emprender su  negocio D. venta D. menú, al principio solo tenia pocos clientes por lo mismo preparaba pocas cantidades con el paso del tiempo la cantidad D. comensales ha aumentado actualmente atienD. a muchas personas que disfrutan D. su buena sazón, para esto ha tenido que usar parte D. su casa para  poner sillas y mesas donD. atienD. al publico que acuD. en busca D. su buena comida, D. ese modo les brinda comodidad sus clientes quienes mayoritariamente son  trabajadores D. la zona y estudiantes D. un instituto que esta cerca D. su casa, además D. eso reparte pedidos para varios negocios D. la zona, Yolanda es feliz por que su negocio crece cada día además cuenta con la ayuda  D. su único hijo y una sobrina, gracias a su trabajo ha podido darle una buena educación a su hijo ya que ella es madre soltera, ella sabe que su negocio crecerá mas, para eso se esta preparando, quiere tener su restaurante D. manera formal con atención al publico ahora esta terminando la construcción en una parte D. su casa y su préstamo le servirá para terminar el piso D. su local, como miembro del grupo “EL BELLO AMANECER”  tiene el cargo D. presidenta  una gran responsabilidad por que dirige a 10 socias, que al igual que ella tratan se surgir en sus negocios.

* Yolanda esta con chompa celeste y pantalon blanco.
texts.en:
Being a good cook was the reason that maD. Yolanda deciD. to start a restaurant business.  At the beginning she had few customers and thus she only maD. small amounts of food, but with time, the quantity of meals needed  increased and now she has many people who enjoy her good food.  She has had to use part of her house to put tables and chairs where she serves the public who come for her good food.  Most of her customers are workers from the area and students of the institute that is near her house. She's able to offer them a comfortable place to eat.  She also delivers food to various businesses in the area.  Yolanda is happy that her business is growing more every day and  since she is a single mother, one of her sons helps her.  She knows that the business will grow more and she is getting ready for this. She would like to have a more formal restaurant for the public and she is completing the construction of a part of the house.  The loan will help her finish the floor of the restaurant area.  She is a member of the group El Bello Amanecer where she is the president.  This is a big responsibililty since the is in charge of 10 members, who like her, are trying to improve their businesses.

Yolanda is the one with the blue sweater and white pants.

loans.use: To finish putting down the floor of her new restaurant

loans.name: Khoem's Group

texts.en:
The loan group in Voat Svay Village in Takeo Province consists of four people. Mrs. Khoem C. has been selected by the other members to be the group leader. Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose. 

Mrs. Khoem C. is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land. She grows and sells rice to support her family. She has two children who are students. Her husband, Mr. Thor Tam, is a duck breeder and construction worker. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand it, so Mrs. Khoem C. is seeking a loan to buy more ducks.

loans.use: To buy more ducks

loans.name: Narangerel

texts.en: Narangerel D. is 33 years old. She lives with her husband and three children in the Yaarmag District of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She lives with her family in a ger, a yurt or traditional Mongolian housing tent in a rented fenced area. Her oldest two children both attend a local secondary school. Narangerel sells coal and firewood in her district. Her husband helps her with the business. She started her business in 2009 with working capital of 100,000 MNT. She has operated a successful business and, today, her working capital exceeds 450,000 MNT. Thanks to her business, she is able to provide for her family by earning 350,000 MNT per month. In the future. she plans to establish her own firewood and coal trade center. Narangerel is a helpful, hardworking person who says, "I want to buy my own house and fence." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more coal and firewood at wholesale prices and to increase the working capital for her business. [Editor's note: For information about fences in Mongolian ger districts, see The Role of a Fence in the Ger District.]

loans.use: To purchase more coal and firewood at wholesale prices

loans.name: Uranchimeg

texts.en: Uranchimeg T. is a 48-year-old single mother who lives with three adult children in the Han-Uul district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a rented house and fence. Her oldest son helps her in her business, her middle daughter attends university, and her youngest son studies painting at the vocational training center. Uranchimeg operates a retail meat business out of a rented stall at the local market in her town. She started her business in 2010 with working capital of 100,000 MNT. After several months of hard work and a loyal customer base, her working capital now exceeds 500,000 MNT. She would like to expand her business in the near future and further increase her product line. Since operating her business, she is able to provide for her family. Uranchimeg is a helpful and hard-working person who says, "I work hard to buy my own house and fence for my family." She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase and preserve more meat in order to increase her working capital. [Editor's note: For information about the role of fences in Mongolian ger districts, see The Role of a Fence in the Ger District.]

loans.use: To purchase and preserve more meat
